title: Sabzara
text:
Sabzara Ali is a student in Statistical and Data Sciences. She is a tenured professor at Holyoke Community College. When not teaching data science, he enjoys rock climbing, biking, and reading. ## Student Hours

title: 1st_Maps
text:
#install.packages("maps")
library(maps)
map()
Here are some maps from the map package. 1

title: 1st_Maps
text:
The world

colours<-c("blue","pink","orange","red") 
map(database = "state", regions = c("california","oregon","washington"), col=colours,fill=TRUE)#map.cities                                  









colors<-c("blue","pink","orange")


map(database = "world", regions=c("Indonesia","China","Australia"))

title: 1st_Maps
text:
The US

maps::map(database = "state")









map(database = "state", regions = "Massachusetts")









map(database = "county", regions = c("Massachusetts"))
map.cities()









new_england <-c('Vermont',"Massachusetts","Connecticut", "Rhode Island", "New Hampshire", "Maine")

map(database = "county", regions = new_england)
map.cities()








You try:
First maps

Add another map of California, Oregon and Washington.

Color this map. hint: type ?map() into the console to read the documentation.

Color the map with three colors of your choice.
Color the border only.


Make a world map with China, Indonesia and Australia.

title: Fancier Maps
text:
We can use leaflet to make some fancier maps.

#install.packages("leaflet")
library(leaflet)

Manual here Here is a text on leaflet.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles()





Let’s put Smith College on the map. Here’s the lat and long.

#we made the icons for the school and home. We first saved these objects, like gave them the name and then used awesome markers yo chnage the icons for each of these.

home_icon<-awesomeIcons()
schoolـicon<-awesomeIcons("education")

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College") |>
  addMarkers(lng=74.87,
             lat=34.0837,
            label="srinagar") |>
            
  addAwesomeMarkers(lng=74.87,
             lat=34.0837,
            label="srinagar",
            icon=home_icon) |>
            
  addAwesomeMarkers(lng =-72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College",
             icon= schoolـicon)        





Whooops. We need a negative sign to indicate west.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")






leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")





You try:

Put your home city and Smith College on the same map.
Use awesomeIcons() to make your home look like a home and smith look like a college.

You will first need to save the icon an object. (Maybe the home is called home).
Hint: Use icon “education”, “book”, “sleeping” for the college icon.
Then you will need to use addAwesomeMarkers().

Finally add this webpage to your index.qmd and make sure it renders correctly.


#install.packages("leaflet")
library(leaflet)

title: Lec 02: In-class Exercise: Scatterplots
text:
Today’s Dataset
This dataset comes from Pioneer Valley Data and documents estimates of population characteristics for each municipality in the Pioneer Valley.


Step 1: Load Packages

# Load the ggplot library
library(tidyverse)



Step 2: Read the Data

pioneer_valley_2013 <- read.csv ("data/pioneer_valley_2013.csv")
pioneer_valley_2013_dictionary <- read.csv("data/pioneer_valley_2013_dictionary.csv")



Step 3: View the Data

# Write your code below to check the column names for pioneer_valley_2013 
names(pioneer_valley_2013)

 [1] "LEVELCD_NAME"       "STATE"              "COUNTY"            
 [4] "COMMUNITY"          "YEAR"               "TIME_TYPE"         
 [7] "CEN_MEDRENT"        "CEN_MEDOWNVAL"      "CEN_HUYEARBLT"     
[10] "RENT_COSTS30"       "MEDAGE_WF"          "PER_COMMNOTSNGLCAR"
[13] "PER_COMMALONECAR"   "PER_COMMBIKE"       "PER_COMMCARPOOL"   
[16] "PER_COMMOTHER"      "PER_COMMPUBTRANS"   "PER_COMMWALK"      
[19] "PER_COMMWORKHOME"   "AVG_COMMUTETIME"    "WORK_OUTCOMM"      
[22] "WORK_INCOMM"       




Step 4: Recreate This Image Using the ggplot() Function
(Full size image in your downloaded folder/img folder.)


# Write your code below
pioneer_valley_2013 |>
ggplot( aes (x= CEN_MEDRENT, y= CEN_MEDOWNVAL)) +
  geom_point() +
 labs( title= "Housing Charaecteristics",
       x= "Median Gross income",
       y= "Med Value")       










Step 5: Recreate This Image Using the ggplot() Function
(Full size image in your downloaded folder/img folder.)


Hint: We need the function scale_y_continuous(), and the labels argument needs to be set to scales::percent. Check the help pages for this function scale_y_continuous() to see how to format this!


# Write your code below

pioneer_valley_2013 |>
ggplot ( aes (x= AVG_COMMUTETIME, y= WORK_OUTCOMM)) +
geom_point() +
scale_y_continuous(label= scales::percent) +
 labs( title= "Commuting Characteristics of Municipalities, 2013",
       x= "Mean Commute Time",
       y= " Percent Work Outside the Community They work in")  








Discussion: Which of the following does each point on this plot indicate?

A person
A municipality
A commute
A county

Answer:


Step 6: Create a Linegraph Using the ggplot() Function
Refer to the ggplot2 cheatsheet to what kinds of variables you need to create a linegraph. geom_line() draws a continuous function, x axis is often a variable related to time, y axis is a numerical variable. Based on this, can you find two variables you think that are appropriate in the pioneer_valley_2013 data frame to draw a linegraph? Remember to add titles and axes labels for your linegraph.

# Write your code below
pioneer_valley_2013 |>
ggplot ( aes (x= AVG_COMMUTETIME, y= CEN_MEDRENT)) +
geom_line() +
 labs( title= "Commuting Time and Rent, 2013",
       x= "Mean Commute Time",
       y= "Median Gross Rent")
